text:
- So we manage our higher
education products.

Anything that you would do
online, just like test-taking,

we manage the reliability
of all of those services.

A lot of our applications
were on on-prem data centers.

Generally, there's a lot
of overhead with that,

patching, worrying about
the physical systems.

And getting everything to the
cloud was paramount for that
because it was on aging infrastructure,

and when things go down,
students can't take tests,
people can't do their certifications,

and these are very
high-pressure situations.
We did like a lift and shift of sorts
of those applications over to AWS

'cause that gave us kind
of some breathing room

so we could refactor
all of our applications
and modernize them to support what we need
for operations in the future.

This solution was using
AWS's Resilience Hub
to take a look at a very high level
of like what our applications do.

Like, is this actually a
mission-critical application,

or can it actually go
down for a little while
and not impact our operations?
We were able to take a look and say,
"Okay, we need multi-Region here,
we need single Region here."

And again, the Resilience
Hub was critical to that
because we were able to input values
and very quickly understand

what applications actually
are important to Pearson.

What we can do now that
wasn't possible before

was focus on the core
aspect of the business

and not just worrying about
operations day to day.

We can quickly identify
issues, respond to them,

and then go back to what's
important for the business.
(gentle bright music)
